caseTitle: IN THE MATTER OF CONSOLIDATED SUITS: WRIT NO
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana, in a consolidated suit involving Ahumah Ocansey and the Centre for Human Rights & Civil Liberties (CHURCIL) against the Electoral Commission and the Attorney-General, addressed the constitutional right of prisoners—particularly remand and convicted prisoners—to vote in public elections under Article 42 of the 1992 Constitution. The plaintiffs challenged Section 7(5) of the Representation of the People Law, PNDCL 284, which disqualified detention centers as places of residence for voter registration, thereby disenfranchising prisoners. The court held that this provision was inconsistent with constitutional guarantees of the right to vote and affirmed that remand prisoners retain their voting rights unless lawfully disqualified. The judgment emphasized the importance of protecting fundamental rights, even in the face of logistical challenges, and rejected the argument that the case was moot despite the 2008 elections having passed, citing the recurring nature of elections and detention. The court ultimately declared Section 7(5) unconstitutional to the extent it denied remand prisoners the right to vote.
verdict: The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, declaring Section 7(5) of PNDCL 284 inconsistent with Article 42 of the Constitution to the extent it disenfranchises remand prisoners.
citations: Gorman & ors v The Republic [2003-4] SCGLR 784
rationaleHighlights: Article 42 of the 1992 Constitution grants the right to vote to all citizens over 18 and of sound mind, without exception for prisoners.
Section 7(5) of PNDCL 284 unconstitutionally disenfranchises remand prisoners by denying them residence status in prisons.
The court rejected mootness, noting the recurring nature of elections and detention.
The state has a duty under Article 45 to promote and protect fundamental rights, including voting rights.
Denial of voting rights undermines civic responsibility and human dignity.
The balance between individual rights and public interest must not override constitutional guarantees.
confidenceNotes: The summary is based on a detailed judicial opinion from the Supreme Court of Ghana with clear articulation of legal reasoning and citations. Information extracted is highly reliable and directly sourced from the judgment text.
